ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Improving metal-enhanced photoluminescence by micro-pattern of metal nanoparticles: a case study of Ag–ZnCdO system

Affiliation.OrgDivision: State Key Laboratory of Silicon Materials

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Micro-pattern of Ag nanoparticles and Ag film is inserted between ZnCdO film and the substrate to enhance the photoluminescence (PL) of ZnCdO films, achieving enhancement ratio of 21.2 and 7.1, respectively. Time-resolved photoluminescence shows that the PL lifetime of Ag/ZnCdO films is longer than that of bare ZnCdO, which is attributed to surface modification and surface plasmons coupling. The improved enhancement in the sample with Ag pattern is attributed to the fact that periodic Ag structure offers additional scattering mediums and thus increases the light extraction efficiency.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: ZnCdO, CdO alloyed with ZnO, can emit light from ultraviolet to blue even green spectral range by controlling Cd-contents and may be a potential material for the blue–violet optoelectronic devices [1]. However, compared with the GaN-based optoelectronic devices, the ZnO-based ones have much lower luminous efficiency [2–4], which largely limits the wide use of ZnO-based materials. Due to the above reasons, it will be of great significance if the band gap emission of ZnCdO is enhanced.

Surface plasmons arising from a collective oscillation of electrons in metals have been widely utilized to realize luminescence enhancement of semiconductor materials and devices [5–9]. Various metals have been used as the surface plasmons (SPs) source for improving luminescent properties of ZnO-based materials [10–13]. For ZnCdO, the band gap emission is enhanced by 8 times with Au film and 12 times with Au nanopattern by Yang et al. [14, 15]. Generally, periodic metal structures are helpful to the extraction of the emission light, thus able to achieve higher enhancement ratio than metal films. However, most of the emission enhancements reported before were based on the structure that metals capped on the top of the luminescent materials. Due to the reflection loss of metals, to some extent, the intensity of incident light and the emission light can be weakened, which thus inevitably influences the enhancement factor. On the other hand, the metal-on-ZnO structure has a great disadvantage when the metal patterns are prepared by solution process, such as photolithography and templating method using monolayer of polystyrene (PS) spheres. During the patterning and liftoff processes, various organic solvent may severely destroy the surface of ZnO. Therefore, an alternative structure is desired to avoid these disadvantages.

With SPs resonance wavelength in the range of 390–460 nm [16], Ag is selected as the SPs source to realize perfect match between the luminescence of ZnCdO and SPs resonance. In this work, we report the improved enhancement of light emission from ZnCdO films by inserting Ag micro-patterns between ZnCdO film and the substrate. Due to the SPs coupling and the passivation of surface states, the luminescence intensity of ZnCdO is enhanced by inserting Ag film into ZnCdO/silicon interface. The luminescence enhancement is significantly improved by applying Ag micro-pattern compared to Ag film, which is attributed to the improved light extraction efficiency by periodic Ag structure.

Section1.Heading: Experiments
Section1.Para: Ag micro-patterns were fabricated by the standard photolithography. Briefly, positive photoresist was first spin coated on Si substrate. It was then covered with a pattern mask and exposed to ultraviolet light. The desired patterned template can be obtained after development. Ag film was then deposited by electron beam evaporation on the template, and the remaining photoresist was subsequently removed by acetone. This procedure produces Ag micro-patterns on the substrate. In order to testify the roles of micro-patterns played in the luminescence enhancement, Ag films were also prepared on the cleansed silicon substrate under the same condition. The Ag layers were deposited by electron beam evaporation (SKY DZS-500), and the thickness was estimated in situ using a quartz-crystal microbalance. The morphology of Ag films and micro-patterns was examined by a HITACHI S-4800 field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM) and a SPI 3800 atomic force microscopy (AFM). ZnCdO films with thickness of about 230 nm were deposited by pulsed laser deposition (PLD) system with a Zn0.9Cd0.1O target at 250 °C and under oxygen pressure of 40 Pa. ZnCdO films on silicon were also prepared as a control sample under the same condition. ZnO samples with the same structure were also prepared for comparison.

X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (ESCALAB 250XI, XPS) was carried out to analyze the chemical state and composition of Zn and Cd elements, with a monochromatized Al Kα source (1,486.6 eV). The crystallographic structure of the samples was evaluated by the Bede D1 X-ray diffraction (XRD) system with Cu-kα radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm). Optical absorption spectra were acquired on an Agilent 3600 UV–vis–IR spectroscopy. Photoluminescence measurements were performed on a FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer (Edinburgh Instruments), and a He–Cd laser (325 nm) was used as the excitation source. A streak camera was utilized to record time-resolved photoluminescence spectra. Both the photoluminescence (PL) and time-resolved photoluminescence (TRPL) spectra were obtained at room temperature.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussions
Section1.Para:
The structure of the samples is demonstrated in Fig. 1. Ag metal layer, consisting of Ag films or micro-patterns, is inserted between the substrates and ZnCdO films. In the commonly reported structure [10, 11, 14, 15] with the metal layer on the top, both the incident and emission light are partly reflected by the capping metal. In our work, however, the loss of light intensity can be avoided by applying the new structure. Moreover, this method protects the chemically active ZnCdO from the various solutions during the patterning process. The morphologies of the Ag films and micro-patterns are shown in Fig. 2. The Ag micro-patterns are ordered in a large area, as demonstrated by the overall SEM image in Fig. 2a. Both the SEM image in Fig. 2a and AFM image in Fig. 2d demonstrate that Ag micro-patterns are composed of closely packed Ag blocks with disklike shape and a diameter of 4 μm. Figure 2b further demonstrates that the Ag micro-disks are composed of many Ag nanoparticles. AFM measurements suggests that the continuous Ag film and Ag micro-patterns have a root-mean square (RMS) roughness of about 2.8 nm, which means that they have a relatively rough surface to scatter SPs energy into photon emission [17]. A line scanning profile of the micro-pattern (Fig. 2e) reveals that the height of the Ag pattern is about 27 nm, with roughness comparable with its film counterpart. Since the Ag film and micro-pattern were deposited at the same condition, the thickness of Ag film is also assumed to be 27 nm. The absorption spectra of Ag film and micro-patterns are plotted in Fig. 3. Both samples show SP resonance peak around 455 nm, which is typical for Ag metal. The broad resonance absorption band covers the near band edge PL of ZnO and ZnCdO. Compared with ZnO, it is clear that the energy match between ZnCdO PL and Ag SP is better.
Fig. 1
Schematic diagram of metal-enhanced photoluminescence in ZnCdO films. Ag film or micro-pattern is inserted between ZnCdO film and the substrate. Upon light excitation, the energy of the excitons can be resonantly coupled to the SPs modes at metal/semiconductor interface, and then light is recovered from the SPs modes through proper scattering medium
Fig. 2
AFM images of a Ag film and b Ag micro-patterns. The corresponding line scan c, d shows a height of ~27 nm for the Ag micro-pattern. The Ag disk has a diameter of 4 μm. The scan is along the gray line in (a) and (b). The RMS roughness of both samples is about 2.8 nm. e SEM image of the Ag micro-pattern, clearly shows the Ag disks
Fig. 3
Absorption spectra of Ag film and Ag micro-patterns. The PL peaks of ZnCdO and ZnO films are also indicated

XRD pattern of the ZnCdO film is shown in Fig. 4. Besides the signal from silicon substrate, a strong peak at 34.3° and a weak peak at 47.5° can be observed, corresponding to the (002) and (102) planes for wurtzite ZnO, respectively. The narrow peaks suggest reasonable crystal quality of the film. Compared with the pure ZnO, the diffraction peaks of ZnCdO slightly shift toward small diffraction angle, consistent with the substitution of Zn by larger Cd atoms [18]. XPS core level spectra of Zn 2p3/2 (1,022.0 eV) and Cd 3d5/2 (405.7 eV) from the ZnCdO film, as shown in Fig. 5, demonstrate that both Zn and Cd elements exist in the oxidized states [19]. According to the XPS results, the Cd incorporation is about 6.7 at.%.
Fig. 4
XRD pattern of ZnCdO film
Fig. 5
XPS core level spectra of a Zn 2p3/2 and b Cd 3d5/2 for ZnCdO film. Cd content is determined to be ~6.7 at.%

All samples exhibit strong violet emission with peak position around 411 nm (Fig. 6), which matches well with the band gap of Zn1−x Cd x O (x = 0.067) [14, 18], indicating effective incorporation of Cd into ZnO. We note that the Ag film and micro-patterns do not have any PL signals. The deep level emission is negligible, indicating a reasonable crystal quality of the films. Both Ag films and micro-patterns realize PL enhancement of ZnCdO. For ZnCdO/Ag pattern, the enhancement ratio reaches about 21.2, which is much larger than that of ZnCdO/Ag film (7.1) and the previous reports [14, 15]. For the ZnO samples, similar enhancement are achieved, but with much lower enhancement ratio (1.6 for ZnO/Ag film and 2.9 for ZnO/Ag pattern). The probable mechanism for the Ag enhanced ZnCdO emission includes coupling between the spontaneous recombination and the SPs arising from the Ag interface, as well as the passivation of surface states by Ag [20–22]. It is reported that strong SPs coupling will happen if the PL photon energy and the metal SPs are close [8]. The different PL enhancements from ZnO and ZnCdO can be attributed to the fact that the SPs energy of Ag matches better with PL from ZnCdO, as indicated in Fig. 3.
Fig. 6
Room temperature PL spectra of the ZnCdO/Ag film, ZnCdO/Ag pattern and bare ZnCdO. All samples show a strong band gap emission around 411 nm and negligible deep level emission. Ag film and Ag micro-pattern sample exhibit a PL enhancement ratio of 7.1 and 21.2, respectively. The inset shows the room temperature of the similar ZnO samples, with enhancement ratio of 1.6 for ZnO/Ag film and 2.9 for ZnO/Ag pattern

For deeper insight into the enhancement mechanism, we performed the TRPL on bare ZnCdO, ZnCdO/Ag film and ZnCdO/Ag pattern, respectively. The PL decay spectra, as illustrated in Fig. 7, are fitted with a biexponential decay, and the effective lifetime is obtained by
$$ \tau = \varSigma_{i} A_{i} \tau_{i}^{2} /\varSigma_{i} A_{i} \tau_{i} $$

[23], where τ
i is the decay time and A
i is the weight factor of each decay channel. It can be seen that the bare ZnCdO film shows the fastest decay rate, with lifetime of 15.3 ps. The lifetime of ZnCdO with Ag patterns is 24.9 ps, which is longer than that of the Ag film sample (20.0 ps) (Fig. 7). The results indicate that SP-coupling is not the only factor that contributes to the PL enhancement; otherwise, the lifetime of the patterned sample would have been the shortest according to
$$ \tau_{\text{ZnCdO}} = (R_{\text{r}} + R_{\text{nr}} )^{ - 1} $$
τ ZnCdO

, where R r and R nr represent radiative and nonradiative recombination rate, and R SP is the rate of SP-coupling. Similar observations have been reported by Liu et al. [20] in Pt–ZnO system. Accordingly, we attribute the increase in lifetime in the samples with Ag to the passivation of surface states, which can decrease the nonradiative recombination rate.
Fig. 7
Room temperature time-resolved PL spectra of bare ZnCdO (red), ZnCdO/Ag film (green) and ZnCdO/Ag pattern (blue); the brown lines are the fitted lines of the three spectra. The lifetime is 15.3, 20.0 and 24.9 ps, respectively, with a biexponential model

Since Ag films cover larger surface area of ZnCdO than micro-patterns, better surface passivation is expected in the film sample. If only surface passivation effect works, the lifetime of the film sample would have been longer than that of the pattern sample. However, our results show that PL lifetime of ZnCdO/Ag film is shorter than that of ZnCdO/Ag pattern. This can be interpreted in terms of the Purcell enhancement factor (F P). Metal films are reported to realize larger Purcell factor (hence shorter lifetime) compared with metal nanopatterns, provided that the thickness of films and the height of nanopatterns are the same [21]. Since the average thickness of Ag film is larger than Ag pattern, ZnCdO/Ag film is expected to realize larger Purcell factor than ZnCdO/Ag pattern. The Purcell enhancement factor (F P) can be expressed as 1
$$ F_{\text{P}} = \frac{{\frac{1}{{\tau_{{{\text{Ag}} - {\text{ZnCdO}}}} }}}}{{\frac{1}{{\tau_{\text{ZnCdO}} }}}} = \frac{{\frac{1}{{\tau_{\text{R}}^{*} }} + \frac{1}{{\tau_{\text{NR}}^{*} }} + \frac{1}{{\tau_{\text{SP}} }}}}{{\frac{1}{{\tau_{\text{R}} }} + \frac{1}{{\tau_{\text{NR}} }}}} $$
F P

The larger Purcell factor of ZnCdO/Ag film sample implies that the lifetime of ZnCdO/Ag film is shorter than that of ZnCdO/Ag pattern. The result also means that it is SPs coupling rather than surface passivation that dominates the PL enhancement.

Based on the above discussion, it is obvious that the PL enhancements by Ag inserting are attributed to the coupling between the SPs arising from the Ag/ZnCdO interface and the spontaneous recombination of excitons from ZnCdO, as well as the decreased nonradiative coupling rate by the passivation of surface states. It, however, cannot explain the much higher enhancement ratio in micro-pattern sample. It is well established that there is a momentum mismatch between the photons and SPs at the resonant energy, and SPs carrying large momentum are unable to transform into light directly, unless SPs give up the additional momentum to make up the momentum mismatch [24, 25]. Generally, surface roughness of metal particles or periodic metal structures can act as scattering medium, with which SPs lose some momentum and are able to couple to light [8, 20, 24]. Micro-pattern array of metal nanoparticles, fabricated by simply applying a Cu TEM grid as the template, has been demonstrated to enhance PL of semiconductor quantum dots [26]. In our work, Ag nanoparticles in the films with RMS roughness of 2.8 nm can act as an effective scattering medium. For the micro-pattern, both the periodic structure and nanoparticles in the disk contribute to the process, leading to more efficient PL enhancement. Therefore, ZnCdO/Ag micro-pattern has much stronger PL intensity, although the Purcell factor is lower.

In a previous work, Yang et al. [14] reported a PL enhancement ratio of ~8 in Au film/ZnCdO structure. Our TRPL results are similar to theirs, and their interpretation is also applicable in our case. However, our ZnCdO/Ag pattern sample shows much larger enhancement. This can be due to the use of periodic metal structure as an additional scattering medium, and the use of a different structure as demonstrated in Fig. 1 to avoid the reflection loss of both excitation and emission light.

The next challenge will be improving the electroluminescence (EL) properties of ZnO-based materials and the ZnO-based light emitting diodes (LED) by this improved structure. It is expected that this method can enhance the luminous efficiency of ZnO-based devices and promote their wide applications.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: In conclusion, we fabricated highly ordered Ag micro-patterns with a large area. By inserting Ag micro-patterns between ZnCdO and the silicon substrate, the band gap emission of ZnCdO is enhanced by 21.2 times. The additional scattering centers offered by the periodic Ag nanoparticles result in the further improved PL enhancement in the micro-pattern sample. Meanwhile, a longer PL lifetime of ZnCdO/Ag than that of bare ZnCdO indicates that the passivation of the surface states in the ZnCdO film by Ag capping can reduce the nonradiative recombination rate. Therefore, the coupling between the spontaneous recombination and the surface plasmons arising from the Ag interface, the passivation of surface states and the improved light extraction accounts for the PL enhancement. The results suggest that the improved light extraction is the dominant factor of the PL enhancement in ZnCdO/Ag micro-patterns sample.
